stem:
A 5-month-old baby presented to ER with sudden onset of episodes of inconsolable crying. Each episode lasts 2-3 minutes, 15-20 minutes apart and the child draws up his legs towards the abdomen during an episode. They have become more frequent since the onset and there were few episodes of bilious vomiting. No history of fever.

The most likely diagnosis is
disc:
Intussusception is classically described as a triad of abdominal pain, palpable sausage-like mass, and passage of currant jelly. But these features are seen in only <15% of the patients. The only presenting symptom may be abdominal pain.

Infantile colic is common in children <3 months of age.

A midgut volvulus can present in any age but most commonly in infants and young children. The initial presentation is usually bilious vomiting. There may be upper abdominal distention and features of peritonitis. In advance cases, there may be abdominal wall erythema on examination.
